DOC.HEAD: Judge Lifts Ban on Pennzoil Suits
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge in Chevron Corp.'s suit over Pennzoil Co.'s alleged clandestine takeover attempt lifted restrictions Wednesday on Pennzoil's ability to file countersuits in other courts. U.S. District Judge Thelton Henderson refused to extend an order imposed by another federal judge Dec. 7 that prohibited Pennzoil from suing anywhere on related issues without approval of the San Francisco federal court. Henderson noted that Pennzoil had denied any intention of suing, said Chevron's claims to the contrary were based on speculation, and added that the local court had the power to prevent inconsistent rulings even if other suits were filed elsewhere. The decision was a skirmish in Chevron's battle to force Pennzoil to sell its newly acquired $2.1 billion, 8.8 percent share of Chevron's stock and prohibit it from buying more stock without court approval. San Francisco-based Chevron also is seeking to validate the anti-takeover measures its directors took around the time of the disclosure of Pennzoil's purchases three weeks ago. Pennzoil, based in Houston, said it was using $2.1 billion of its $2.6 billion net proceeds from a settlement of its suit with Texaco as a long-term investment in Chevron for tax purposes. Pennzoil said it might invest the other $500 million in Chevron stock but denied any intention of a takeover of the nation's fourth-largest oil company. But Chevron, citing Pennzoil's past attempts to acquire oil property, contended the rival firm intended a hostile merger or a forced restructuring. Chevron's suit accuses Pennzoil of violating federal laws requiring advance notice and a 30-day waiting period before major stock purchases by anyone but a passive long-term investor. Pennzoil, saying Chevron's suit is based on unfounded suspicions, has asked Henderson to dismiss the case. A ruling is pending. Wednesday's decision involved an order Chevron obtained Dec. 7 from Chief U.S. District Judge William Ingram forbidding suits by Pennzoil without approval from the local court. Chevron said Pennzoil would inevitably sue to challenge the restrictions on takeovers, and argued that restrictions were needed to avoid inconsistent decisions.
